title: Fyvie Castle Walks

images.title: Anne Burgess / Fyvie Castle
images.caption: The imposing façade of Fyvie Castle, which is made up of five linked towers.

images.title: Andrew Wood / Fyvie Loch from the boathouse
images.caption: Fyvie Loch from the boathouse

images.title: Martyn Gorman / Boat house and waterfowl at Fyvie Castle
images.caption: Boat house and waterfowl. Part of the large ornamental lake at Fyvie Castle. The boat house would have been used by fishing parties from the castle. The swans are whooper swans visiting for the winter.

images.title: Mike and Kirsty Grundy / Kitchen Garden Fyvie Castle
images.caption: Kitchen Garden. This garden is dedicated to growing Scottish varieties of fruits and veg: tayberries, sunberries, raspberries and all sorts of goodies.

images.title: Alison Mack / Oldwood House, Fyvie Castle
images.caption: Oldwood House. This grand looking house with tall chimneys lies in the extensive grounds surrounding the castle.

images.title: Mike and Kirsty Grundy / Fyvie Castle Fountain or Bird's Nest
images.caption: Castle Fountain or Bird's Nest. Oystercatchers nest here every year oblivious to visitors.

images.title: Anne Burgess / Fyvie Parish Kirk and Kirkyard
images.caption: Fyvie Parish Kirk and Kirkyard. The church is dedicated to St Peter. It was rebuilt in 1808, repaired by James Henderson in 1863 and reconstructed with additions in 1903 by Alexander Marshall Mackenzie.

description:
This 13th century castle in Aberdeenshire has some splendid walking trails to follow around the surrounding grounds. In the park you'll find well maintained footpaths taking you to beautiful gardens, woodland trails and the picturesque Fyvie Loch. The 18th century loch is a great place for wildlife watching with nesting swans, geese and ospreys to look out for.
Inside the castle you can learn all about its history and view a fine portrait collection, antiquities, armour and lavish oil paintings. The castle is in the care of the National Trust for Scotland who charge for entry. You can see more details on the link below.
